newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia navy chief says country's seas are safe.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia navy chief says country's seas are safe.

text.p: Indonesia has said the safety of its waters is not under threat from pirate attacks despite the recent hijacking of a Malaysian oil tanker, the official Antara news agency reported on Monday.
"So far our seas are safe. Our warships are patrolling every day of the year," Indonesian navy chief Vice Admiral Arief Kushariadi was quoted as saying.

The news agency said Kushariadi was responding to a report by an office of the International Maritime Bureau (IMB) in Kuala Lumpur which had said Indonesian waters were home to a high percentage of the world's pirates.
Kushariadi said the navy had not yet confirmed whether a Malaysian gasoil tanker hijacked off the coast of Singapore last month was now in Indonesian waters.
Indonesia has pledged to use two Australian-made Nomad N-22 aicraft and patrol ships in the search for the tanker, which was hijacked by six unidentified pirates.
The Malaysian-owned vessel, Suci, and its $600,000 cargo of gasoil were stolen about 60 miles off the east coast of Singapore while heading for Sandakan port in the Malaysian province of Sabah.
The hijacking came to light after 15 of the ship's crew were rescued by a fishing boat operating from a port on the Indonesian island of Batam, around 50 miles (80 km) south of Singapore.
The crew of 11 Indonesians, two South Koreans and two Burmese had been set adrift by the hijackers two days before they were rescued.
A further two Indonesians, both engineers, were detained aboard the ship by the pirates.
